pageContext.claim: “We solved that problem yesterday. I expect to see the [food] supply chain as strong as ever -- maybe stronger, for certain reasons.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump was referring to an executive order that directed processing plants to continue operating. But plants have increasingly been exporting to China while U.S. consumers face shortages, a Reuters analysis of government data showed. Pork supplies tightened as the number of pigs slaughtered each day plunged by about 40% since mid-March, but shipments of American pork to China more than quadrupled over the same period. "The disruptions mean consumers could see 30% less meat in supermarkets by the end of May, at prices 20% higher than last year, according to Will Sawyer, lead economist at agricultural lender CoBank," Reuter said.
